text: The 17th and 18th centuries saw a bunch of top-notch wars, but today we're going to focus on the Seven Years War,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: also called the French and Indian Wars, because it was the first truly global war.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: In fact, no less a historian than Winston Churchill called it the First World War.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: But we've been so Eurocentric here on Crash Course that all we are going to say about the entire war in Europe
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: is that Prussia and Great Britain fought France and Austria,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: and that the Austrian Habsburgs wanted to win back Silesia, which they failed to do there.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: That's all you get, Europe.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So the Seven Years War lasted for anyone? Anyone?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: 23 years?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: But as it happens, by sheer coincidence, you are not necessarily wrong.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So the when. The Seven Years War began in 1756 and ended in 1763.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Unless you believe, as many historians do, that the Seven Years War lasted 23 years
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: because it was really a continuation of the war for Austrian succession.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Then you have the fact that much of the information in today's episode
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: is taken from a book called The Global Seven Years War, 1754 to 1763, A Nine Year Period.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: As for the who, it was mainly fought between the British and the French, seen here,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: reenacting the knife fight from either Beat It or West Side Story, depending on your age.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: But some of the British were actually Americans, and both the British and the French were supported by American Indians.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And there was fighting in India between Indian Indians, the British and the French.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And as previously noted, the French were fighting the Prussians and the British were fighting the Austrians.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The where? Europe, the continental US, the Caribbean Sea, off the coast of Africa, India, basically the world.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And the why? Ostensibly land.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: British colonists wanted to expand into land west of the original 13 colonies.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And that land was technically held by the French, who left it alone except for a bunch of trading posts,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: and they were like, je ne veux pas l'anglais!
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Thank you, four years of high school French.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Anyway, the war wasn't really about land, it was really about our old friend, trade.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: The British wanted to expand into the American interior to allow for more colonists,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: because the British benefited both from the export of raw materials from the Americas,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: and the import of British consumer goods to the Americas.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So more colonists meant more trade, which meant more wealth, which meant ever fancier hats.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And the French realized that this British Atlantic maritime trade was making Britain so rich
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: that Britain might come for France's actually valuable colonies, which were not in the continental US,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: but those slave-based sugar plantations in the Caribbean.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So the fighting began around here, and while the British did send over actual British troops,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: much of the early fighting was done by colonial militias.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Probably the most famous commander of British troops was a Virginia colonel named George Washington.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: In fact, he may have actually started the shooting at the Battle of Fort Necessity in May of 1754.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Washington was captured in that battle, but then he was immediately released,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: because 18th century war was super weird.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Anyway, the real North American action was in New York and Canada.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: At the Battle of the Plains of Abraham in 1759, for instance,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: the British defeated the French and captured the city of Quebec.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Both the British commander, General Wolfe, and the French commander, General Montcalm,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: were killed in that battle, with the death of the former being immortalized in this famous painting by Benjamin West.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: As indicated by the picture, almost all the battles in North America featured significant participation by Native Americans.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Different Native tribes sided with both the British and the French, but as a broad generalization,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Native Americans were more likely to support the French.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Up to this point, shrewd Indian tribes had been able to play the British and the French off each other
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: and maintain a degree of autonomy for themselves.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And as long as the French were present, the British were prevented from encroaching too much
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: on lands Native Americans were using for hunting and agriculture.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Now, we haven't talked much about American Indians, mostly because they were geographically isolated
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: and didn't have a written language, but let's at least give them a thought bubble.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Before the arrival of the Europeans, most Native Americans lived in tribal groups,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: and they subsisted on a combination of small-scale agriculture and hunting and gathering,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: depending on where they were situated.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: There were too many tribes to generalize about specific social structures,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: but it's probably safe to say that in terms of gender,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: they were much more egalitarian than the Europeans who they met up with,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: which may explain why European women who were taken captive by Indians
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: sometimes preferred to stay with the tribe rather than be rescued,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: although that's somewhat controversial.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: One thing we can say about the Indians,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: their notions of what it meant to hold property were very different from those of the Europeans.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Individual Indians did not own land in the European sense.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: They used it, and not always particularly intensively.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Europeans, when they came to North America,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: had a hard time even recognizing that the Indians were raising crops,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: because their forms of farming were so different from European agriculture.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So the French, and especially the English,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: just assumed that the Indians weren't improving the land,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: which meant that they didn't own the land,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: so that meant that it was okay for Europeans to take it.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: But, as you might imagine, that was problematic for the Indians.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: In general, Indian tribes initially got along better with the French than with the Dutch or English,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: because one, the French did not settle in large numbers,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: as they were mostly traders and fur trappers,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: and two, French missionaries who made the journey to the Americas were Catholic,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: often Jesuits, who were so intent on converting the Indians
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: that they took the time to learn Indian languages
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: and try to make Catholicism more amenable to Indian religion.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The end result of the war, a greatly reduced French presence on the American mainland,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: meant that Indians could no longer easily play the British and French off each other,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: which opened the floodgates of British settlers.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: In the end, the American Indians were perhaps the biggest losers of the Seven Years' War.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Thanks, Thought Bubble.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So 2,000 miles south in the Caribbean,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: there was also quite a lot of fighting between the British and the French over sugar colonies.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Most of these were naval battles, and by 1761, Spain got involved,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: because, you know, they had some sugar colonies of their own.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: While these battles get a lot of ink, it's interesting to note that by far the greatest threat to combatants was disease.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: By October of 1761, the British had lost about 1,000 men to war and 5,000 to disease.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Meanwhile, in West Africa, the British and the French were fighting there, too, because, you know, why not?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The British attacked the French at a trading post called Saint Louis.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Oh, Stan, don't make me say it right. Fine.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Saint Louis.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And at a town called Gouray, both in Senegal.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Why? Well, trade, of course.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Senegal was the main source of gum Arabic, which is notable for many reasons,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: but most importantly, it is a key ingredient in the Diet Coke and Mentos phenomenon.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So, of course, the British wanted lots of it.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And the French were also fighting the British in India.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: That's more plausible.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: But as throughout most of its history, the real power in India lay with local kings and princes, sometimes called Nawabs.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And these princes, just like their European counterparts, were constantly vying for power and control over more territory.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And to get it, they often enlisted the help, especially the military help, of Europeans.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: This is what happened in the most notorious event in the Seven Years' War in India, the Black Hole of Calcutta.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: In June of 1756, the British governor of Calcutta, Roger Drake, made the mistake of insulting the emissaries sent by the Nawab's Siraj ad-Dula,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: who duly besieged and captured the English garrison of 500 with his own army of 30,000.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Drake escaped to nearby ships with the town's women and children. You know the old saying, women, children, and governors first.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: But the town's defenders remained, and the survivors were imprisoned in a small, windowless room that came to be known as the Black Hole.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And 40 of 63 prisoners suffocated overnight. This story is mostly famous in a war that killed a million people,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: because the British press exaggerated the numbers in order to build support for the war in India.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Not the last time that exaggerations of enemy brutality would be used to gin up support for a war.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Perhaps the most interesting thing about the military campaigns in this part of the world is that, at least initially,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: they were not undertaken by governments themselves, but by corporations that had their own armies.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The British East India Company was the most successful of these corporations, primarily because of the military skill of its leader, Robert Clive.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Oh, it's time for the open letter?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: An open letter to Robert Clive.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: But first, let's see what's in the secret compartment today.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Oh. Bubbles.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: That makes sense, Stan. The British East India Company was involved in several early market bubbles.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Mmm. Bubbles.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Dear Robert Clive, you were a complicated man and not entirely likable, but you did win a very important battle at Plassey in 1757.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And the way you won it says a lot about the relationship between Europe and its colonies.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So the key to your success was a conspiracy to overthrow the existing Nawab orchestrated by a Bengali banking family called the Seths.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: No, Stan. The Seths. Yes. Come on.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And in thanks for your support of their conspiracy, the new Nawab quickly signed a treaty with your company, the East India Company.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And thereafter, the British had effective control over trade in Bengal and the French were excluded from it.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: This was an incredibly valuable region because it produced silk and inexpensive cotton cloth for export,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: and it gave the British a decisive advantage over the French and eventually allowed them to control all of India.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And you accomplished this, Robert Clive, primarily by fomenting revolution.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So by now you've probably figured out that since the French kept losing battles, they eventually lost the war.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The main peace treaty signed in Paris in 1763 limited French presence in the Caribbean, in India, and in North America.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Although not completely, otherwise they couldn't have sold Louisiana to Thomas Jefferson in 1803.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So France was obviously dramatically weakened, but overall, so was Britain.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: One thing rarely mentioned is the actual human cost of war.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: As many as a million combatants died in the Seven Years' War, but even that doesn't tell the whole story.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: In the 18th century, armies usually fed themselves by foraging, which really meant just pillaging the countryside.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: In Europe, a single Prussian province lost a fifth of its population to pillaging,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: and in North America, settlers in frontier regions lived in constant fear of raids.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And one of the perhaps lesser known outcomes of the war was the systematic deportation of French Acadians from Maine to Louisiana, where they became Cajuns.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Meaning that the stars of the television shows Lobster Wars and Swamp Wars are basically the same people.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: What's that?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: There's no television show called Swamp Wars?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Stan, cancel everything and get me on the phone with the Discovery Channel.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: One last thing about wars, they are expensive.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: In 1756, the British national debt was 75 million pounds.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: In 1763, it was 133 million pounds.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Someone had to pay for this, and the British felt it was only fair that the American colonists should foot the bill.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And those taxes, which helped fuel the American Revolution, were a direct result of the Seven Years' War.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So in one way, winning the Seven Years' War cost Britain its first empire.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: But when we remember that it was a global war, and especially when we think about what happened in India,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: then the Seven Years' War also begins to look like the beginning of Britain's second and much greater empire.
speaker: SPEAKER_00
